Topic.Title: What the analysts should have asked...

Message.Msg: "The publishers were trying to keep the price high. Apple does not need it high and neither does Google." This is a lie. It was Apple who approached the publishers and hatched the scheme to control prices and they currently charge very aggressive commissions on ebooks and apps the former of which drives prices up and keep Apple from gaining anything but a tiny share of that market. "Apple makes its money from hardware..." Which shows you why they are adept at dealing with Amazon and ebooks. "Google makes money from Ads." I see. This makes the money different somehow I guess. It means they can burn shareholder's cash digitizing all the books in the world and then being unable to monetize it. Yeah, a lot of good their "money" has done them. "Neither needs to charge a penny above the royalty fees on digital content. They shouldn't. They should sink Amazon quickly and harshly." But instead they (Apple) do the opposite of what you say. Apple not only charges more than a penny, they charge 30%. Theirs is a culture of high margins, even if that marginalizes them to a minor player (ebooks). That culture does not tolerate your notion of "not charging a penny for blah, blah..." "Amazon is trying to sell their products as loss leaders..." So does Walmart, what's wrong with that? "Google and Apple will port the content to their respective clouds (Google already does it with music). Sure, legacy books will still be in Amazon's proprietary format, but books aren't like music. People don't typically read them many times." Actually, reading them has nothing to do with. The greatest consumers of books like to keep a library of them to be re-read from time to time and to share with others. For reference. But most of all because most consumers do not read books in serial fashion. They tend to accumulate many books that go unfinished which they hope to come back to later. Shorts don't realize this because many are non-book people so they don't understand how books are used or really much of anything about the business. "It is the FLOW that matters... This will all become clear by the end of 2013, but probably much sooner...." Yes, that should be about the time that shorts really start to feel the pain as the recent investments begin generating levels of profit no current short could begin to imagine.

Message.Title: Is Amazon going to have enough cash?
Message.Msg: Amazon is bleeding around $1B of cash per quarter. With some effect of state taxes on sales and a deteriorating macro environment, will Amazon have enough cash to support their ambitious expansion program and hardware? Amazon is down to $2.6B is excess cash. That's all they have to burn through. Beyond that, they will need to issue stock, since nobody will fund them with debt at reasonable rates.

Topic.Title: Simple answer for amzn being up in AH

Message.Msg: I think what most people forget is that many investors and analysts seem to be swayed by emotion & a good story rather than the financial metrics. The quarter's numbers and guidance weren't horrible but weren't great either. Kinda mixed bag. However, there are some warning signs: 1) Revenue growth continues to decelerate, probably due to a larger base each quarter. 32% is the slowest revenue growth we've seen over the past 5 quarters. This comes despite higher CapEx so more CapEx is having a smaller bang for the buck. 2) The balance sheet is starting to show signs of cracking. Shareholders equity is down. Cash and cash equivalents are down due to the high CapEx spend rate. 3) They do a tricky thing IMHO by reporting numbers excluding foreign currency translation. This is not typical of way most companies report and suggests that they are trying to "manufacture" the best numbers possible. The actual 10-Q will have the proper numbers but most investors won't take the time to dig up anything more than the press release. Anyway, if you include FX translation, the comprehensive net loss is $0.32 a share. Since ultimately, shareholders care about income in $ rather than income in Euros or other currencies, this loss isn't a good sign.

Message.Title: Emphasis on Gross Margins
Message.Msg: I am trying to understand the emphasis on gross margins this year. It was sighted as a major factor in positive response to Q1 results and again this Q - see excerpt from Reuters article: Amazon's gross profit margin was 26.1 percent in the second quarter, up from 24.1 percent a year earlier, according to Scott Tilghman, an analyst at Caris & Co. "There was tremendous growth in Amazon's higher-margin services," Tilghman said. "I can't find a quarter in the past nine years when Amazon's gross margin was over 26 percent." However according to the companies own 10-Q report: "Gross margin increased in Q1 2012 compared to the comparable prior year primarily due to service sales increasing as a percentage of total sales. We believe that income from operations is a more meaningful measure than gross profit and gross margin due to the diversity of our product categories and services." While gross margin may be up, the more meaningful measure is down.

Topic.Title: Simple answer for amzn being up in AH

Message.Msg: True, but when they build a fulfillment/data center, there are not-insignificant costs that don't get capitalized but expensed, so you can't say their opex shouldn't increase at all. Besides, they don't just construct a building and get done with it. The center must be stocked with equipement, inventory, powered, cooled/heated, and actually managed and operated by folks on payroll. Since those expense hit before the new infrastructure gets fully utilized, but would stay relatively stable as utilization rate goes up, so the operating margin gets hit at first and then improves over time. In AMZN's case though, it's not just fulfillment/data centers. They are also greatly increasing spending on content licensing and Kindle engineering/marketing. AMZN's goal seems to be becoming the platform for delivering both hard and soft products over the internet, which would turn it into something of an utility company for e-commerce, and they are essentially putting all the profit they generate toward that goal.

Message.Title: Gross margins and the hot dog man
Message.Msg: OK we can make this simple. You have a hot dog stand in NYC on the corner of Wall Street and Willam Street. You have been lucky enough to have that location for 40 years. You buy the best hot dogs for 80 cents each, with the fixings your average dog costs you $1. You sell your dogs for $4. So you make $3 a dog and have a gross margin of 300%. You work daily (you do take off market holidays) from 10 - 6. At 5:30 one day you have 20 dogs left which you will have to throw away...remember you've been there 40 years, you are an institution, no one wants stale hot dogs the next day. So do you reduce your price of those last 20 dogs which will lower your gross margin. Or do you just throw those dogs away? Sometimes we make business a lot more complicated than it is.

Message.Title: Gross Margins expansion is bad for Amazon
Message.Msg: When it comes from third party sales instead of first party sales. Amazon's Gross Margins on 1st party sales has averaged 22%. Amazon's Gross Margins on 3rd party sales is 100%. However, Amazon charges a 12% seller's fee. 3rd Party sellers cannibalize 1st Party sales. Instead of buying directly from Amazon with a 22% margin, Amazon is getting a 12% fee. That's why you see revenue figures slowing while gross margins improving. I think slowing Kindle sales also help gross margins since they are selling for a breakeven or loss. It is pretty clear to me that Amazon's strategy is to go after everything. Their Sales Tax Advantage strategy has been torpedoed so they are being forced to build more warehouses locally to reduce shipping costs to compensate. Building out logistics is clearly increasing operating expenses with more leases, headcount, etc.. Forecasts are for a loss next quarter as this expansion continues. This is a negative. If it was more profitable to build more warehouses, Amazon would have done this a decade ago. It remains to be see what Amazon's operating margins will be after this expansion is completed. Walmart right now is the leader in this area. Third Party Sales are increasing. This obviously helps margins, but it also cannibalizes first party sales. Amazon does not want to turn into another EBAY. Media sales. There is a lot of competition here, but this is a high margin business and Amazon needs to build market share. However, I think it is a really dumb move to drive growth through Kindles and potentially Phones. Amazon has not done a good job historically building it's own hardware and keeping up with product refresh cycles is very expensive. Amazon is growing in all different directions, but there are a lot of clouds on the horizon especially when their primary business is going to get hit with Sales Taxes requirements. Amazon needs to push a nationwide internet sales tax through Congress ASAP. Once California sales start getting charged sales tax in September, there is going to be a flood of sales going to other online retailers like Abe's of Maine for electronics or 5th Ave of New York. Amazon's tax advantage is going to shift to other online retailers which California hasn't targeted yet. I think the picture will become more clear after this holiday season and whether Amazon deserves a PE of 300.

I think so too. Still, this is an easily manipulated stock cause only 15% float is not under control by insiders and institutions. If any one the major holders blink, that's when AMZN's valuation will start getting in line.

Topic.Title: Question: What's the fair P/E for AMZN?

Message.Msg: You know as well as everyone else here that PE is a meaningless measure for either growth companies or companies with extremely low (or no) earnings. What would you say if AMZN showed $0.00 eps? That its stock price should be $0? That is so naive it defies any logic and makes the people harping about P/E look very foolish. The guy who says "30 is a fair PE" is dreaming. This company has annual sales of 57B and you're saying the market cap should be 6B. That is beyond ludicrous and shows a total lack of understanding of company valuations. AMZN is priced at a low 1.8x sales when in my mind it should be closer to 3x giving a target price of $383/share. This is still cheap compared to companies like AAPL (3.6x sales) or even MSFT (3.2x sales) or the crazy 4.3x for EBAY or 4.6x for GOOG. Even non-tech companies like MCD and KO trade at over 3x sales. When selling private companies people start the conversations at 3x sales, its a good rule-of-thumb starting point for valuation and its a bit surprising that AMZN is trading at just 1.8x sales along with companies like GE or PM or CSCO when in my mind it should see faster growth than those three. PE is a really poor measure for a company willing to zero out its bottom line by dumping all available money into growth both in its existing markets and by trying to enter new ones. If you're looking for high valuations start with P/S and go from there, P/E can be extremely misleading.

Topic.Title: Gross Margins expansion is bad for Amazon

Message.Msg: <-This. Furthermore- I really don't even think the analysts are calculating "Gross Margin" correctly in this situation. Amazon doesn't supply us with a "gross profit" line item as most companies do, thus analysts are falling back on total revenue - cost of goods. The problem is, for Amazon the cost of goods line item is only impacted by direct product sales- the service sales are treated as 100% gross margin. But that's not right, when you look at direct competitors - Ebay doesn't have 100% gross margin and neither does Netflix or Rackspace. Cost of services should be taken into gross margin consideration when you're a services company. For Amazon those cost of services are lumped in to the fulfillment, marketing, technology and content line items. They aren't broken out so we can't figure out gross margin for the services sector.

Message.Title: AMAZON ON ITS LAST RUN: THE GROSS MARGIN FAIRY TALE
Message.Msg: Guys, let the share price alone. But Amazon is up for a serious problem now. We are running on the last wheel now where pumpers refer to a gross margin that is not even reported by Amazon. The slight increase in third party sales might contribute to increased margins and no, I don't think it is positive to offer a website for less then committed business partners that are searching for ways to skip the Amazon sales fee as soon as they see any opportunity But the real bang is probably the shift of costs to Selling General and Administrative and other fixed costs (say brick and mortar fulfillment centers, increased headcount in this and other areas and some Kiva robots in the future...) what was variable costs (cost of sales in form of shipping costs) until now. The fun part is, Amazon is still a very seasonal business, so they have to build out warehouses, so that they can keep the inventory to serve Q4 demand as they said and have a lot of overcapacity for the rest of the year. Say slack even in normal business environments due to seasonality. So, look for improving gross margins (that, I say it again, have never been reported by Amazon), in exchange for ever decreasing operating margin and negative earnings. Only imagine that the Online sales tax bill will not be passed on the national level and see Amazon going into a downward spiral. This is particularly important, because their own products, the Kindle line, will even make them more losses as they have to collect sales tax on their Kindles in the of the biggest US states, California and Texas, as of Q4 and Q3 2012. Means increase the price of the Kindle or take the bigger loss to compete with the Google Nexus, iPad Mini etc. Amazon is ready for a lot of trouble. Their CFO even admitted it openly. Operating cost will increase faster than revenue for the foreseeable future. Prepare for one of the biggest short stories in history!!! I see evaporation of anything from 30 to 70 billion in market cap in a couple of weeks to months when this starts. They are starting to drain their cash now. They will even have problems to even build out the inventory they need in front of the higher demand season...

Message.Title: Little Jeff is sitting on his dad's knee ...
Message.Msg: Little Jeffy is sitting on his father’s knee talking about his future: Dad: So, Jeff, what do you want to be when you grow up? Jeff: I want to be one of Forbes’ 30 richest people! Dad: Great, how are you going to do it? Jeff: I’m going to start a company that will sell everything to everybody. Dad: Well that’s ambitious. But what about competition? If you want to sell everything, won’t you have a lot of competition? Jeff: That won’t be a problem because I’ll sell everything for less than everybody else. Dad: But Jeff, you’ll never make any money! Jeff: I won’t care. Dad: But if you don’t make any money, how will you get to be so rich? Jeff: I’ll sell stock in my company. Dad: Jeff, who’ll buy stock in your company if it doesn’t make any money? Jeff: Everyone. Dad: Jeff, the people on Wall Street are pretty sophisticated. They’ll know you’re not making any money and they won’t promote your business or stock. Jeff: Yes they will. I’ll tell them that I’ll make money someday. By the time they realize someday never comes, I’ll have sold billions of dollars of my stock. Dad: Jeff, you’re being naïve. People aren’t that stupid. Jeff: We’ll see.

Message.Title: Analysts following the crowd...
Message.Msg: From Barrons: Kerry Rice, Needham & Co.: Reiterates a Hold rating. Rice, like Kopelman, thinks the operating profit outlook is not a big deal, writing that “we believe investors have become indifferent to Amazon’s high investment levels. Instead of leading the dialogue with sound fundamental research, it sounds to me like many analysts are following the lemmings, saying in effect, if the stock is up it must be ok. Here's another: Kevin Kopelman, Cowen & Co.: Reiterates an Outperform rating, noting the company’s “strong growth” in North America, helped by sales of media. Kopelman is not concerned about the lower operating profit outlook, writing “Amazon’s Q3 non-GAAP operating profit guidance of $(75)-225 million was below our expectations as the company builds out ahead of the Q4 holiday season” but “Amazon has also beaten the high end of its profit guidance for three straight quarters.” Kopelman raised his year revenue outlook to $61.87 billion from $61.07 billion, while cutting his EPS estimate to $1.37 from $2.11 One question: if its a good thing to invest and build out ahead of Q4 holiday season, why is he cutting EPS estimates for the full year (which naturally includes Q4) and cutting them dramatically?

Message.Msg: Read hussmannfunds article for this week,his articles are really great. He lays out why we are in such a messed up situation, that all these interest rates so low is actually really bad for an economy,and he is right because we have the best example in Japan. From his column "This does not reflect a well-functioning economy. To the contrary, if you look across history and across nations, strong prospects for sustained economic growth are typically accompanied by high real interest rates, because the demand for capital is robust and good ideas have to compete for funding. Interest rates are an indication of both the demand for loans and the incentive to save. It is not “stimulative” to depress interest rates in an environment where households, businesses and governments are desperately trying to reduce debt. That policy may insult the value of time enough to deter people from saving, and to reduce the immediate penalty for assuming even larger amounts of debt (as the U.S. government continues to do), but it should be clear that these actions move the economy further from a sustainable equilibrium, not closer to it. "

Message.Title: SCAMAZON: JAN2014 LEAP PUTS ONLY WEAPON TO WIN AGAINST BEZOS CRIMINAL HEDGE FUND GANG
Message.Msg: Amazon.com: The Fantasy Keeps Growing In my very first article on Seeking Alpha, back in October 31 2011, I said that Amazon.com (AMZN) would soon be posting losses. At the time, the earnings estimates for the quarter I was referring to were north of $0.40 per share, and those for the quarter that Amazon.com just reported were north of $0.50 share. Amazon.com has just reported $0.01 per share for that quarter, and guided towards a loss for the next one. So the losses really are about to arrive. Meanwhile, at that time the theory for Amazon.com's continuous earnings underperformance was that it was investing in its future, and in more and more warehouses to bring about that future. So the story went that as soon as this investment stabilized, the earnings would flow. However, even then there were several reasons to believe Amazon.com was telling a bogus story, such as: Investments are mostly capitalized and depreciated over time, so the earnings impact is not as large as Amazon.com paints it; Other growth companies in the past didn't have to excuse poor profitability with ongoing investments. This is true even of companies in sectors similar to Amazon.com's, such as Wal-Mart (WMT). Anyone can check Wal-Mart's history and confirm that in spite of strong growth and investment, earnings never flagged; More glaringly, most of Amazon.com's infrastructure investment is taking place in the U.S., yet most of the margin compression is taking place internationally, as can be seen from the imploding earnings contribution from the international segment. As I said at the time, "Having arrived here, it should be perfectly clear to anyone that the reason being advanced for Amazon.com's margin compression is bogus. And it being bogus means it will persist.". As we know today - but wasn't the consensus expectation back then - the margin compression persisted, confirming the misleading nature of the story. http://seekingalpha.com/article/757641-amazon-com-the-fantasy-keeps-growing?source=email_rt_article_readmore&ifp=0

Message.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase
Message.Msg: Forbes had an excellent article on the gross margin expansion. http://www.forbes.com/sites/abegarver/2012/07/26/amazons-q2-2012-results-is-gross-margin-our-new-prophet/ Here is the relevant point. <<<<Under a 3P model, Amazon only reports fees paid by vendors to Amazon and not the cost of goods sold. This practice results in much higher gross margin as a percent of revenue and is allowed under a little understood accounting guideline called EITF Abstract Issue No. 99-19: Reporting Revenue Gross as a Principal Versus Net as an Agent.>>> And the question on the call from the woman at Golman confirmed it. Heather Bellini - Goldman Sachs Question on the gross margin, continues to climb up, and I was wondering if you could give any commentary there around how agency versus wholesale and eBooks is contributing to that? Tom Szkutak Yeah, the bigger issue is not that, it’s related to overall 3P, a number of factors of different factors certainly driving the improvement in product gross margins that you are referring to. But as it relates to 3P, it’s on the broader 3P. So if you take a look at from a units perspective, third party was 40% of our total units in Q2. That’s up from 36%. So it’s approximately 400 basis points increase as a percentage of total units which is certainly one of the factors that you are seeing there. For me this is just playing with some very insignificant numbers.

Topic.Title: Reasoning behind the gross margin increase

Message.Msg: What Amazon reports as COGS is simply not comparable to COGS reported by similar competitor. If it was, then EBAY would have 100% gross margin, Rackspace would have 100% gross margin. They don't. And has anyone else noticed that revenue from the core business is now LESS than COGS+Fulfillment? In other words, marginal profit on their core business is negative- Amazon now literally loses money every time they sell something outside of 3P and AWS.

Message.Msg: There is no random luck. I understand the behavioral algorithms that dominate the market these days. I buy when they overextend to the upside. Actually, I was out from 175 because I decided to focus on LULU and CMG which were more overextended. You'll note I had almost no posts here (nor positions between then and 228). I am up on AMZN and a lot. As to Google, it will break out over the next year while AMZN craters. Actual investors understand that even at scale with improved margins, AMZN's cash flow will pale compared to Google's. The facts are quite clear. Amazon's ROIC, ROA, ROE, inventory turns, EBITDA and FCF all are declining as it overbuilds low value, high capital intensity physical infrastructure... Gross margin means nothing if it requires excessive fixed asset investment to increase margins... Amazon will end up losing ground in electronics once taxes are charged. It will end up with a purchasing bias toward lower value density goods, reducing revenue growth and increasing shipping/logistics as a % of revenue. Save this post. We'll see how it turns out.

Topic.Title: SCAMAZON: JAN2014 LEAP PUTS ONLY WEAPON TO WIN AGAINST BEZOS CRIMINAL HEDGE FUND GANG

Message.Msg: I keep telling you that AMZN is rising because of a trading cartel, not because there are any rational buyers of AMZN's buildout story. The fact that the story keeps changing and the rationale for higher stock prices is the inept analyst community attempt to shut the barn door after the horses are out. They can not conceive of any real reason for AMZN to be trading north of 100 billion, but like magic, the stock keeps levitating. So they search for some kernel of a story, even though they can barely keep a straight face while shoveling their drivel. The only explanation for the AMZN levitation is limitless buying in the face of short bank accounts being exposed to the trade. The only real money entering the AMZN trade is short money. By any metric, AMZN seems ripe for a fall, so shorts continually enter the fray. The HFT machines and their hedge fund owners have figured out a way to buy and cancel their trades with one another, giving them limitless buying power without any real cash needed for settlement. It's the reason AMZN trades the way it does, gapping in the face of obvious short news, when shorts "rationally" enter the pool. Last night and this morning are perfect examples. AMZN shorts sell the stock, and then the HFT machines take over. They push the stock higher in rapid fire fashion, trading with each other, and then cancelling the trades at the end of the day. The short pain becomes real, and the money transfer from short bank accounts is the fuel that keeps the trade working. As long as there is new short money, the pattern continues. There is no regulatory body to look at cancelled trades. If you could continually rob a bank and never get caught, wouldn't most people? I know you dispute this theory, but the tic data and the trading charts are the compelling evidence. What other explanation for the repeated trading pattern can you provide?
